raw_text:
Volcano drama erupts on BBC One
 
 Supervolcano, a docu-drama about a volcanic eruption in Yellowstone National Park in the US, is among the highlights on the BBC One this winter.
 
 The £178m winter schedule also includes the return of Doctor Who and a drama about Angela Cannings, who was wrongly convicted of killing two of her babies. Sarah Lancashire and Timothy Spall will star in the real-life drama, Cherished. ITV also unveiled their festive season on Tuesday, which includes Stephen Fry in a remake of Tom Brown's Schooldays. Supervolcano, follows in the footsteps of last year's Pompei, which drew 10 million viewers to BBC One in October 2003.
 
 The programme merges science, drama and computer imagery to reveal what could happen if Yellowstone - home to the only currently active supervolcano in the world - were to erupt again. BBC Two will run a two-part documentary, The Science Behind Supervolcano, in conjunction with the transmission. Other educational highlights include a documentary about infamous Mongolian warrior Genghis Khan and Grandchild of The Holocaust. Grandchild of The Holocaust, part of the BBC commitment to Holocaust Memorial Day, follows Adrian, 13, on a journey to uncover the truth about what happened to his grandmother in Auschwitz and Belsen.
 
 New drama includes Archangel, an adaptation of the Robert Harris best-seller, which stars Daniel Craig on the trail of Stalin's diaries in Communist Russia. And Sarah Waters' gets her second adaptation on BBC One with Imelda Staunton and Charles Dance lined up to star in Fingersmith. The adaptation, about a conman in Victorian England, will make an interesting contrast to Julie Burchill's Sugar Rush - a lesbian teenage drama part of Channel Four's winter season. On a lighter note, Jessica Stevenson will star in new BBC One sitcom, The World According to Bex, penned by My Family creator Fred Barron and the Two Ronnies return for a celebration of their classic comedy series.
 
 Fry's portrayal of headmaster Dr Arnold dominates a muted Christmas schedule on ITV1, which sees the channel retreat from broadcasting blockbuster movies in favour of extended soap episodes and popular quiz shows.
 
 Sir Paul McCartney, wife Heather Mills and Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson will join a celebrity edition of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? on Christmas Day. Also on Christmas Day, John Nettles will return in a one-off edition of Midsomer Murders, while two episodes of the new Miss Marple drama will air over the festive period. Films on ITV1 include Gus Van Sant's Finding Forrester, starring Sean Connery, and classics such a Mary Poppins, Star Wars and The Good, the Bad and the Ugly. In contrast, BBC's Christmas season includes terrestrial debuts of the first Harry Potter film, Shrek and Steven Spielberg's AI, as well as new epipsodes of the Vicar of Dibley and the final Auf Wiedersehen, Pet.

* Supervolcano
* Doctor Who
* Cherished (Angela Cannings drama)
* Stephen Fry in Tom Brown's Schooldays
* ITV: Stephen Fry, Sarah Lancashire, Timothy Spall, Genghis Khan documentary, Grandchild of The Holocaust

ITV also unveiled its festive season with Stephen Fry in a remake of Tom Brown's Schooldays, as well as other dramas like Archangel and Fingersmith.

ITV1: Stephen Fry in Tom Brown's Schooldays; celebrity edition of Who Wants to be a Millionaire?; John Nettles returns for one-off Midsomer Murders; classics like Mary Poppins and Star Wars are available.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) will air the latest TV programs this winter, including a documentary about Yellowstone National Park's potential for a supervolcano eruption. Meanwhile, BBC One is preparing new drama series such as "Archangel," "Fingersmith," and "The World According to Bex." The BBC 2 channel will run two-part documentaries on "The Science Behind Supervolcanos" in conjunction with the TV transmission. ITV1 will broadcast a new soap opera called "The World According to Bex." Additionally, a one-off episode of "Miss Marple" and a Christmas edition of the new Miss Marple series will air over the festive period.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Supervolcano docu-drama about Yellowstone eruption is one highlight on BBC One's winter schedule; Doctor Who returns, Genghis Khan documentary runs alongside it, and other shows include adaptations of best-selling books, celebrity quizzes, and festive specials including Christmas films from the West End.
qwen2.5:3b: Volcano drama "Supervolcano" on BBC One highlights a winter schedule including Doctor Who returns and a real-life Angela Cannings drama. ITV’s festive lineup features Stephen Fry in Tom Brown's Schooldays. Supervolcano merges science with computer imagery to depict potential Yellowstone eruption impacts. BBC Two will also air a documentary series “The Science Behind Supervolcano.” Educational programs like "Genghis Khan" and Holocaust-related documentaries are part of the winter schedule. New dramas include adaptations of Robert Harris' "Archangel," Charles Dance in "Fingersmith," and Jessica Stevenson in "The World According to Bex." ITV1's Christmas lineup features light-hearted sitcoms and popular quiz shows, while BBC’s includes terrestrial debuts of Harry Potter films, Shrek, Steven Spielberg's AI, new episodes of "The Vicar of Dibley," and the final episode of "Auf Wiedersehen, Pet."
opencoder:1.5b:
Volcano drama on BBC One: An exploration into the effects of a volcanic eruption in Yellowstone National Park.
 
The programme merges science, drama, and computer imagery to unveil the extraordinary event that could happen if the only currently active volcano remains dead or collapsed. Supervolcano follows the story of last year's Pompei, which was a colossal feat made possible by BBC One's anticipation about October 2003.
 
In addition to scientific revelations, dramas like this one unfurl a deeper understanding of human behavior during a volcanic event. The programme is an invitation to witness life on Earth around Yellowstone National Park as it happens and the effects that could ripple across the globe. It also introduces viewers to more than just volcanoes, including the likes of Doctor Who and Angela Cannings who was wrongly convicted.

The show is part of a winter schedule that includes Doctor Who, Cherished, the science behind supervision, Genghis Khan, Archangel (Robert Harris adaptation), and a Holocaust documentary. phi:2.7b:
The docu-drama Supervolcano will air on BBC One in winter, which also includes Doctor Who, Cherished, Tom Brown's Schooldays remake, and a two-part documentary about Yellowstone National Park supervolcano eruption. ITV's Christmas schedule features new drama Archangel and Fingersmith, as well as soap operas. 

The BBC's season will include documentaries on Genghis Khan, Holocaust Memorial Day, and Grandchild of The Holocaust. There are also new sitcoms, such as The World According to Bex, Midsomer Murders, and the first Harry Potter film. In contrast, ITV is broadcasting extended soap operas and popular quiz shows, with a focus on Sir Paul McCartney and John Nettles' appearances in Who Wants to be a Millionaire?.

Other highlights include *Archangel*, starring Daniel Craig, and *Fingersmith*, featuring Imelda Staunton and Charles Dance. BBC Two will air a related documentary, *The Science Behind Supervolcano*, as well as educational programs on Genghis Khan and the Holocaust. ITV's Christmas lineup includes Stephen Fry in *Tom Brown's Schooldays*, extended soap episodes, and celebrity editions of *Who Wants to be a Millionaire?*. The £2 million winter schedule also includes Stephen Fry's Tom Brown's Schooldays and the second adaptation of Sarah Waters' novel Fingersmith on BBC One. Additionally, ITV unveils their Christmas offerings with films like Finding Forrester, Mary Poppins, Star Wars, and The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly; while BBC presents a mix of educational documentaries including Genghis Khan and Grandchild of The Holocaust along with the drama adaptation of Robert Harris' novel Archangel starring Daniel Craig.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
This winter, BBC One and ITV unveil captivating lineups featuring both drama and educational content. On BBC One, highlights include:

1. Supervolcano ($178m production), a docu-drama exploring the catastrophic consequences of a Yellowstone volcanic eruption, drawing from last year's popular Pompei.
2. Cherished, starring Sarah Lancashire and Timothy Spall, a real-life drama about Angela Cannings, who was wrongly convicted of infanticide.
3. Archangel, an adaptation of Robert Harris' best-seller, with Daniel Craig as Stalin's diary hunter in Communist Russia.
4. Fingersmith, based on Sarah Waters' novel, with Imelda Staunton and Charles Dance.
5. Grandchild of The Holocaust, part of BBC's Holocaust Memorial Day commitment, following a 13-year-old on his quest to discover his grandmother's fate in Auschwitz and Belsen.
6. A lighter note: Jessica Stevenson stars in The World According to Bex, a new BBC One sitcom created by My Family's Fred Barron.
7. Two Ronnies reunite for a comedy celebration.
8. Julie Burchill's Sugar Rush, a lesbian teenage drama on Channel Four.

ITV's festive season features:

1. Stephen Fry in Tom Brown's Schooldays, remade.
2. Genghis Khan documentary and part of the BBC's Holocaust Memorial Day commitment, Grandchild of The Holocaust.
3. A Christmas special with Sir Paul McCartney, Heather Mills, and Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson on Who Wants to be a Millionaire?
4. John Nettles returns for a one-off episode of Midsomer Murders.
5. Two new episodes of the Miss Marple drama.
6. Classic films like Finding Forrester, Mary Poppins, Star Wars, and The Good, the Bad and the Ugly on ITV1.
7. BBC's Christmas offerings include terrestrial debuts of Harry Potter, Shrek, AI, Vicar of Dibley episodes, and Auf Wiedersehen, Pet.
